page.title: 06The Lea Navigation
page.content: In the past the Lea Navigation was used to take raw materials like timber from towns to the north of London into its centre.The materials were carried by barges and these were pulled by horses which walked along the towpath which runs alongside the canal.Today the canal is used for fishing and pleasure cruising.Fishing is very popular because there are many types of fish in the canal.The canal isnÂ£t used for carrying raw materials today.This is because the barges have been outdated by lorries,vans and trains.The towpaths are now used for people to walk on and are also used by fishermen to sit on. The canal is 28 miles long running through the Lea Valley and finishing in the Thames at Blackwall,south of the Isle of Dogs.
